content: The "Energy Freedom and Economic Prosperity Act" is the short title of the legislation. It includes a reference to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for any amendments or repeals. The Act also contains a table of contents outlining the sections, including the repeal of energy tax subsidies in Title I. The "Energy Freedom and Economic Prosperity Act" repeals various energy tax subsidies, including credits for alcohol fuel, biodiesel, alternative fuel mixtures, fuel cell motor vehicles, plug-in electric drive motor vehicles, alternative fuel vehicle refueling property, alcohol used as fuel, biodiesel, renewable diesel, enhanced oil recovery, electricity from renewable resources, oil and gas production from marginal wells, and production from advanced nuclear power facilities. The "Energy Freedom and Economic Prosperity Act" repeals various energy tax subsidies, including credits for carbon dioxide sequestration, energy, advanced coal projects, and gasification projects. It also includes a reduction of the corporate income tax rate. The "Energy Freedom and Economic Prosperity Act" repeals energy tax subsidies, including credits for alcohol fuel, biodiesel, and alternative fuel mixtures. Corporate income tax rate is also reduced. Section 6426 is repealed, with various conforming amendments made to related sections. The table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65 is amended by removing the item related to section 6426. The amendments made by this section apply to fuel sold and used after the enactment of the Act, except for liquefied hydrogen, which applies after September 30, 2014. SEC. 102. Early termination of credit for qualified fuel cell motor vehicles. The text chunk discusses the repeal of Section 30B and related amendments, effective for property placed in service after December 31, 2014. The text chunk repeals Section 30D for new qualified plug-in electric drive motor vehicles and the alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit. Effective for vehicles placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 104 repeals Section 30C for alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit, with conforming amendments and an effective date for property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 105 repeals the credit for alcohol used as fuel by repealing Section 40 and making conforming amendments to related sections. The effective date for these changes is after the enactment of this Act. Section 40A is repealed, with conforming amendments made to related sections such as section 38, section 87, section 196, section 4101(a), section 4104(a), and section 7704(d)(1). The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 is amended by removing section 40A. The amendments apply to fuel produced, sold, or used after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 107. REPEAL OF ENHANCED OIL RECOVERY CREDIT. The Energy Freedom and Economic Prosperity Act repeals Section 43 and makes conforming amendments to other sections. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2014. SEC. 108. TERMINATION OF CREDIT FOR ELECTRICITY PRODUCED FROM CERTAIN RENEWABLE RESOURCES. The Energy Freedom and Economic Prosperity Act amends section 45 for wind energy and section 45(e)(10) for Indian coal. The effective dates for these amendments vary, with wind energy applying to property placed in service after the Act's enactment and Indian coal applying to coal produced after December 31, 2012. Other qualified energy resources have a termination date for property placed in service after December 31, 2013. The Energy Freedom and Economic Prosperity Act repeals credits for producing oil and gas from marginal wells, terminates the credit for production from advanced nuclear power facilities, and repeals the credit for carbon dioxide sequestration. Effective dates for these changes vary, with production in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014 affected. The Energy Freedom and Economic Prosperity Act repeals the credit for carbon dioxide sequestration under Section 45Q, terminates the energy credit under Section 48, and repeals the qualifying advanced coal project credit. These changes apply to carbon dioxide captured after December 31, 2014 and property placed in service after the same date. SEC. 113 repeals Section 48A, with amendments to Section 46 and a clerical change. Effective after December 31, 2014. SEC. 114 repeals the qualifying gasification project credit. SEC. 114 repeals the qualifying gasification project credit under Section 48B, with amendments to Section 46 and a clerical change. Effective for property placed in service after December 31, 2014. The Secretary of the Treasury will set a new flat tax rate to replace existing rates for certain sections, aiming to decrease revenue for 10 years while increasing revenue due to amendments. This new rate will apply to taxable years starting more than a year after the Act's enactment.
